title: Dracunculiasis
parasite_biology:
### Causal Agents

Dracunculiasis (Guinea worm disease) is caused by the nematode (roundworm)
_Dracunculus medinensis_.

### Life Cycle

![lifecycle](/parasites/images/guineaworm/Dracunculiasis_LifeCycle_3.jpg)

Humans become infected by drinking unfiltered water containing copepods (small
crustaceans) which are infected with larvae of _D. medinensis_![The Number
1](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/stomach_1.gif).
Following ingestion, the copepods die and release the larvae, which penetrate
the host stomach and intestinal wall and enter the abdominal cavity and
retroperitoneal space![The Number
2](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/generic_2.gif). After
maturation into adults and copulation, the male worms die and the females
(length: 70 to 120 cm) migrate in the subcutaneous tissues towards the skin
surface![The Number
3](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/generic_3.gif).
Approximately one year after infection, the female worm induces a blister on
the skin, generally on the distal lower extremity, which ruptures. When this
lesion comes into contact with water, a contact that the patient seeks to
relieve the local discomfort, the female worm emerges and releases larvae![The
Number 4](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/generic_4.gif).
The larvae are ingested by a copepod![The Number
5](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/generic_5.gif) and after
two weeks (and two molts) have developed into infective larvae![The Number
6](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/generic_6.gif).
Ingestion of the copepods closes the cycle![The Number
1](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/stomach_1.gif).

### Geographic Distribution

An ongoing eradication campaign has dramatically reduced the incidence of
dracunculiasis, which is now restricted to rural, isolated areas in a narrow
belt of African countries.

### Clinical Presentation

The clinical manifestations are localized but incapacitating. The worm emerges
as a whitish filament (duration of emergence: 1 to 3 weeks) in the center of a
painful ulcer, accompanied by inflammation and frequently by secondary
bacterial infection.

lab_diagnosis:
### Laboratory Diagnosis

The clinical presentation of dracunculiasis is so typical, and well known to
the local population, that it does not need laboratory confirmation. In
addition, the disease occurs in areas where such confirmation is unlikely to
be available. Examination of the fluid discharged by the worm can show
rhabditiform larvae. No serologic test is available.
